text: Welcome to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia!

In this travel guide we’re going to take
you on a whirlwind tour of a city that we
have visited many times before.

Our travels are often dictated by food, and
KL offers a delicious smattering of Malay,

Chinese, and Indian flavours that create some
mouthwatering dishes that keep us coming back
for more.

But because you’re probably coming here
for more than just food, in this video we’ll

be taking you around some of the city’s
main attractions, while also showing you some

popular street markets as well as few of our
favourite restaurants.

Now let us show you 25 things to do in Kuala

Another place to hit up in Chinatown is Petaling
Street (茨厂街).

When the sun sets, this place comes to life,
especially in regards to street food.

You can find everything from clay pot rice
to stir fried noodles, all on a budget!

Now let’s move on the city’s biggest attraction:
the Petronas Towers!

These are twin skyscrapers that once held
the title of tallest building in the world.

We skipped going up the towers, but we did
enjoy KLCC Park, which is the garden directly

in front of the towers, and we also stuck
around to watch the Lake Symphony.

If you’re in the mood to shop Suria KLCC
shopping mall is a great place to do so.

First off, it is going to get way too hot

Once you’re done visiting, there are lots
of vegetarian restaurants right across from

the Batu Caves, so if you’re feeling a bit
hungry, this is a great place to enjoy some
food.

We also visited Merdeka Square, which is a
large green lawn where the Malaysian flag
was hoisted for the first time.

Directly across from the square you have the
iconic Sultan Abdul Building, which you’ll
likely have spotted on more than one postcard.

This building originally housed the offices
of the British administration and it reflect’s
the country’s colonial history.

We just finished visiting Merdeka Square and
we came across a music museum and it is free
admission.
So we're just checking it out now.
It seems pretty cool.
They have a lot of traditional instruments.

So yeah, it is also a nice way to cool down
because it is air conditioned and it is so
hot and humid outside.

There are 3 museums right across from Merdeka
Square, so we hit them all up on the same
morning.

over to the textile museum to see some batik,

and then the KL City Gallery to learn a little
bit more about the city, and grab a snack.

Alternatively, another popular dish that you
can have for breakfast or anytime of day is

Nasi Lemak: a rice dish cooked in coconut
milk and pandan leaf.
It’s pretty tasty!

Going back to sightseeing, you also have KL
Tower, which offers a bird’s eye view of
the city.

And if museums are more your thing, you can
visit the National Museum of Malaysia, which

focuses on culture and history; or the ethnography
museum right next to it.

The National Mosque of Malaysia is also open
to visitors, but unfortunately, we arrived
during prayer times so we couldn’t go in.

Lastly, a quick note on transportation to
help you get around.
Another city another metro system.

So to get around Kuala Lumpur (கோலாலம்பூர்)
you're going to want to take the LRT.
The metro system here.

And you're going to want to get one of these
touch and go cards.

This allows you to load it up as much as you
want on the card.
You scan in and out.

You load up as you need to and as always getting
these cards allows you to not have to go and

buy the individual tickets every time you're
riding it.

So that’s a wrap for our time in Kuala Lumpur,
Malaysia!

We hope you enjoyed following along and that
you go a few ideas of things to do, places

to visit, and of course, foods to eat while
you’re there.

As always, if you have any suggestions of
things we may have missed, feel free to share

those with fellow travellers in the comments
below.
Until next time!
